Haosen(Russell) Xing

Email: haosenx (at) andrew dot cmu dot edu

I am currently a research assistant in Robotics Institute at Carnegie Mellon University, working with Dr. Ge Lv and Prof. Chris Atkeson. My current research is in the control optimization of exoskeleton.


  • Research
  • Projects
  • Publications
  • About me

Research Experience


Task-Invariant Control and Experimental Testing of Lower-Limb Exoskeletons
  • Successfully submitted a paper to ACC 2020
We are using a novel control methodology for wearable robots that prefer task-invariant, energetic control rather than task-specific, kinematic control. It shapes the total energy of the human body with exoskeleton actuators, reducing mass/inertia parameters in body energetics to dynamically offload the weight of a patient. This methodology is ideally suitable for task-invariant tasks because it does not depend on pre-defined kinematic patterns. Using powered orthoses to assist humans in a variety of activities is coming true.
Inertial Tail-like Appendage Use in Quadruped Improves Stability in Diagonal Sequence Walking Gaits
  • abstract
Our work aims to increase the stability of the DS gait by investigating the use of an inertial tail-like appendage. We model the quadruped system as a self-manipulator with an actuated tail in 3D which can swing in not only the yaw direction but also the pitch direction.
Tail Use in Quadruped Improves Static Stability in Diagonal Sequence Walking Gaits
  • abstract
Our work investigates the use of a heavy tail to help stabilize larger-stride-displacement gaits for a quadruped robot. With the help of an actuated tail, such a quadruped can take advantage of the higher stride displacement (about 30% larger) of the diagonal sequence walking gait while maintaining static stability.
Legged System Gait Design and Stability Analysis Using Hildebrand Diagram
  • presentation
The gaits of quadrupedal animals all have footfall patterns by which contact is made between the foot and the ground. Both the order in which the feet make contact and the length of the contact describe the gait. While there are a myriad of gaits quadrupeds could use for locomotion, only a few are routinely seen [hildebrand]. In this case, as Hildebrand diagram is a plot to characterize and compare symmetric quadruped gaits, we can perform gait design and stability analysis for quadruped, hexapod, octopod, etc.
Geometric Mechanics and Quadruped Back-bending
  • paper
  • video
  • presentation
We use geometric mechanics to prescribe gaits with the coordination of leg movements and back-bending motion. We are able to show back-bending in quadruped, especially in salamanders, can improve stride displacement in the forward, rotational and lateral directions. Also, by assuming all stance feet having zero linear velocities, we model the quadruped locomotion on flat ground. We perform the simulation and robot test to analyze how back-bending improves locomotion.
Lower-body Fitting Robot CAD Design and Control
  • presentation
April 2017 – June 2017
This individual project is a part of the Fitting Robot Mannequin Project, aiming to make shopping for clothes, easier and more convenient for the consumer and less cost of sales for the seller. It focuses on the development of a robotic mannequin of the female lower body, which can morph to take the different shapes and sizes those a woman’s body can attain.
Analyze the Decay of Kinetic Energy Downstream with Turbulence using Wind Tunnel
  • report
March 2016 – May 2017
We set up the experiment about the decay of kinetic energy downstream with turbulence, and analyze the power spectrum of down-stream decay.
Micro Generator Design
  • report
March 2016 – December 2016
We develop a micro generator which is at most 0.5cm in diameter and 5cm in length. Such micro electric generator will offer a promising power source for small size electronic devices, like phones, watches, and so on.

Academic Projects


Obstacle Avoidance Trajectory Optimization
  • report
Motion planning is an essential part for autonomous driving vehicles. One interesting subject within this area is planning a trajectory that safely overtakes an obstacle in the front. Our project solves this trajectory planning problem with various optimization based methods including iterative linearquadratic regulator (iLQR), genetic algorithm (GA), and interior point methods(IPMs).
Policy Gradient Tutorial
  • presentation
We gave a oral tutorial about Policy Gradient theorem. We divided the theorem into two main parts: policy gradient for episodic tasks and continuing problems. We included topics like:
Why policy gradient?
What is the advantage of the policy gradient?
How does the policy gradient perform? etc.
We covered some common algorithms,
such as REINFORCE: Monte Carlo Policy Gradient, REINFORCE with Baseline, One-step TD Actor-Critic Q Actor-Critic, Advantage Actor-Critic, Natural Policy Gradient.
Grid World Navigation Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
  • report
Our work is to use reinforcement learning system to solve the problem of agent navigation and largely leverage the reward it fetched in an infinite grid world with a single agent roaming around. The algorithm we have implemented are: Double DQN, Dueling Network, A2C Network, A3C Network, DDPG Network.
Develop a Simple Image Processing Application Named FinePixel Using C++
  • report
This self-designed software has some basic functions like zooming in/out, cropping and rotating.
The following list shows some special features: adjust the temperature, adjust contrast and brightness, adjust the hue, smoothing & sharpening, adjust highlight or shadow, add filters, adjust saturation, skin smoothing, face recognizing, GUI. Our performance target is that the user can use our product to do simple image processing. As our product name shown, it has competitive graphics processing than Instagram.

About Me


Research Interests
Control: optimal control and real-time optimization of human assistive devices
Learning: reinforcement learning / deep learning in locomotion
Education
M.S., Mechanical Engineering, Carnegie Mellon University, 2017 - 2019
B.S., Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Irvine, 2013 - 2016
